results.title: Tears
results.brief_description: The lone desert highway leads from an Aboriginal settlement to a bus shelter which offers both the promise of opportunity and the danger of isolation. For the young teenage girl, the bus out of the desert means hope for legitimacy, freedom and an escape from the scars of a ruthless colonisation. For the boy, the escape might mean leaving behind the only family, community and safety he has ever known. Ivan Sen’s remarkable short film, utilising sparse dialogue and a harshly eloquent mise-en-scene, forces an audience to comprehend the terrible, seemingly futile optimism of will that is required of its young protagonists in imaging a future.

results.title: Acquiring a taste for Raffaella
results.creator_credit: Sandra Lepore, Fotini Manikakis and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The onset of menstruation leads to a curious mix of events when Raffaella shares the news with her traditional Italian Aunt. Together they make some special Italian love biscuits, “biscotti di amore”, with a secret ingredient intimately linked with Raffaella’s menarche. When the object of her affections tastes the love biscuits, surprisingly, he asks for the recipe.

results.title: In the name of the crow
results.creator_credit: Marion Benjamin, Mark Bin Bakar, Peter Kordyl, Robert Bropho, Heather Williams and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description: Most tourists who visit Rottnest Island are unaware of its history. Established as a prison for Aboriginal men around 1840, it was intended as a place for “rehabilitation”. However, accounts of floggings, chainings and hangings flourished on the mainland despite official enquiries and commissions suggesting everything was in order. In this documentary, Robert Bropho takes us to the island and traces the hardship and the suffering of his ancestors that has been omitted from white man’s history.

results.title: Cass: no saucepan diver
results.creator_credit: Wayne Barker and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: In 1982 Aboriginal filmmaker Wayne Barker returned to his home in Broome, Western Australia to make a film about his grandfather, Cass Drummond. The result is this personal portrait of a staunchly self-reliant old man as he looks back on his life in the pearling industry and comments on what it was like to be an Aboriginal earlier this century.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wayne Barker and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: Kylie Tennant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Kylie Tennant drew her inspiration from people she knew, and her exuberant interview is in itself a valuable piece of Australian social history.

results.title: John Blight
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
An insightful and humorous conversation with the renowned Queensland poet brimming with anecdotes about the Depression and the development of his poetry.

results.title: Judith Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
As well as being one of Australia’s more eminent poets and novelists, Judith Wright is an outspoken commentator on conservation and Aboriginal land rights.

results.title: Peter Porter
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
From his book-crammed London flat, Peter Porter introduces a variety of his best-known poems and presents his accessible and humane intelligence.

results.title: David Malouf: an imaginary life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
Poet and novelist David Malouf was filmed in Tuscany, Italy, during the coldest winter there for 50 years, and in Sydney during a steamy summer. To write, he says, you must turn your back on even the most beautiful landscape. Malouf talks about the influences on his work and how he gets into the writing process.
